ratings.comment: His lectures are not as bad as other reviews described. Though the logic is abstract, it's thought-provoking and helps one understand the essence of the subject. It takes effort to grasp his logic, but studying diligently will lead to understanding. While his test questions can be challenging and unexpected, Yunrui's discussion is quite helpful.

Expect a challenging but rewarding class. The lectures are proofs and cover what was in the books. Make sure to always take notes and form discussion groups. The professor was extremely accessible and made it known to everyone that he was open to feedback and to changing the class. The professor fostered discussion and created a great environment.

I was personally extremely underwhelmed with Professor Yethiraj's teaching.  This class is very frustrating and demoralizing.  Content taught in lecture barely corresponds to homework and discussion assignments. I enjoyed the research project that is a component of this class, but would generally not recommend this class.  Avoid Professor Yethiraj.
Very lackluster teacher, the exams where not on content that we learned. Very hard to know what to study for.

The class is tough, but Professor Yethiraj seems to truly care about his students when you reach out. He's teaching tough material and a lot of the learning is done outside of the class. Overall he is truly caring and a great guy.

Probably the single worst professor I've ever had. Completely inaccessible out of class, didn't comply with requested accommodations, and gave absolutely no study materials. Showed a grad student friend what he had us doing for this class and he was baffled by how needlessly difficult the curriculum was.

I had the worst experience with Prof. Yethiraj. The first midterm grade had an average of 39%, and he spent the next lecture berating us because we "obviously hadn't studied enough". I ended up sending an email to the Chair of the Chemistry Department about his horrible behavior. I learned absolutely nothing from this class.

Taking Prof. Yethiraj's class has been the most frustrating experience I have had at UWM. His real lack of enthusiasm in teaching makes the already hard class topic even harder. The recorded lectures are very dry, without any in-detailed explanation about how they are derived. Don't take his class if you actually want to learn something.

He's the worst professor I've had at UW-Madison. His philosophy is to not test on homework material and he gives hardly any idea what will be on tests. First exam avg was around a 40%, and he thought the avg would be much higher. He took an entire lecture to explain how easy the questions were and didn't listen to criticism or general suggestions.

Possibly the worst professor in the country. Low exam averages with unfair questions, unclear lectures, doesn't follow syllabus, doesn't respond to emails. Turned 50 min lectures into 8 min lectures when classes were moved online. Textbook is useful for homework but unrelated to test material. Avoid this professor at all costs.

SOS THIS IS BY FAR THE WORST PROF UW-MADISON HAS TO OFFER!!! He not only doesn't care about your learning. He doesn't put in any amount of effort but suggests that to learn his class you should do every problem in the book. His exam averages are low, 38. They don't connect to lecture content or hw or the course at all. Steer clear of Arun or suffer

When the class average was a 38 on the first midterm, mostly due to ambiguous questions, he accepted no responsibility at all and spent an entire class berating the students for not studying hard enough. Homeworks can be impossible and the graders give points anyways because they couldn't find solutions. Exams didn't correlate to homeworks at all

If you have a choice I advise not taking 562 with Dr. Yethiraj. He waited until the week before the exam before assigning the first homework assignment and followed it up with an exam having nothing to do with homework, readings, or lectures. The average was a 38% and he plans to make next exams harder due to COVID-19 forcing exams online.

Yethiraj is a smart guy who's willing to help a lot in office hours; that being said, he gives zero idea for test content.  There's little cohesion between lectures,  homework, and tests.  Don't take it unless you are STRONGLY interested in chemistry and confident in math.  Good things were the easy curve and sense of class community.

Professor Yethiraj is brilliant and was kind to me personally. However, he doesn't provide any kind of warning about what exams will test for. Homework has nothing to do with tests, neither do textbook readings, and lectures are too ambitious. Other reviews are spot-on.

THIS IS PHYSICAL CHEM. There's lots of math involved - you need *at least* two semesters of calculus. Professor Yethiraj goes through a lot of complex derivations we don't really need. He definitely knows what he's talking about, but he presents an excessive amount of information and doesn't specify what to focus on for the exams. Good luck!

Hello,  I'd recommend Chem 109 (or 109 honors if you want the honors) over this class. You learn a lot of the chemistry you need in that class. 115 is a challenging waste of your time. That said, Prof Yethiraj is very smart but he considers all material important and doesn't tell you what to focus on. Choosing what to study is a judgement call.
The exam is much easier than the materials talked in the class but overall it is challenging.

This class will make you question your academic abilities. Goes thru many long derivations; explanations are sometimes unclear. He does not provide any prep materials for exams, so you'll have to decide what's most important to study. Exams are challenging but doable. "Curve" is generous; everyone usually gets at least a B. TA is excellent.
